info.name: 19.2.1 Oracle Identity Cloud Service Authentication API - Acc Rec + Terms of Use is new here
info.description:
Customzing the log in experience with Oracle Identity Cloud Service has required that end users have 3-party cookies enabled in their browsers. This is a problem to many users, especially those providing B2C applications where they can't impose any controls on end-user behavior.

Oracle Identity Cloud Service has eliminated that dependency by introducing new authenticating APIs based on the concept of a state machine, where request responses inform an application client what has to be done next.

The requestState provided in each request response is used in the next request, providing the client with the information that it needs to process the request, and then provide the next set of operations allowed.

item.name: Authentication Without MFA
Step 1: Authentication Request with AppName

request.description:
This step obtains the initial requestState to then continue with the authentication flow. The appName is optional, but is used in this step for testing purposes.

The user submits their credentials in Step 2 as the first factor, which is the username/password.

The requestState in the response received contains the following information:

- creationTime
- tenantName
- appName

For the Next Step:
- The client must pass the credentials, which are the username and password
- The client must pass the requestState that was received in the Step 1 response (this step).

item.name: Step 2: Username/Password Submisstion

request.description:
This step sends the username and password and the requestState that was received in the Step 1 response.

In the response received during Step 2 
"nextOp": "enrollment" indicates that the user should enroll in an MFA factor as the next step.

Note that BYPASSCODE is missing in the response since the user can't enroll using a Bypass Code. The Bypass Code should be generated by the user using My Profile or by requesting that an administrator generate one for them.

The policy evaluation happens in the background and the next applicable operation (either enrollment or authentication) is sent in the response.

item.name: Step 3: Initiate Offline TOTP Enrollment Request

request.description:
This step requests to enroll in the offline TOTP factor. In this request, you must include the requestState that was received in the Step 2 response.

The requestState in the request contains the following information:

- deviceId
- authFactor
- tenantName
- appName
- ecid

For the Next Step:
The client must pass the requestState that was received in the Step 3 response.

To get a QR Code to scan for testing purposes:
You must copy the value of the qrCode "content" value and use an online QR Code Generator (such as: https://www.the-qrcode-generator.com) to generate a QR Code to scan using the Oracle Mobile Authenticator App to get the otpCode to use in Step 4.

item.name: Step 4: Submit Factor Credentials

request.description:
This step submits the factor credentials and the requestState that was received in the Step 3 response.

The otpCode attribute contains the passcode generated on the third-party code generator app.

The requestState in the request contains:

- deviceId
- authFactor

Because deviceId and authFactor are included in the requestState, the client doesn't need to specify this information in the request.

In the Response, 
"nextOp": "createToken" indicates that the client can request the token in the next request.

The user can also choose to continue to enroll in other factors. Should the user continue to enroll, an extra call should be made to get the details of all factors (Get Backup Factors) that a user can enroll in.

Included in the requestState that is received in the response:

- creationTime
- tenantName
- appName

item.description:
A mobile app uses either a one-time passcode (TOTP) or push notifications to prove that the user has possession of the mobile device. Only the mobile app that is in possession of the user's secret key can generate a valid OTP. Provisioning the secret key can be done online or offline. 
 
This enrollment scenario is using the user's credentials, the requestState, and the offline MFA TOTP.
 
Identity Cloud Service users can use the OMA app or any supported third-party authenticator app that they want to generate OTPs. However, users must use the OMA app to receive push notifications. Use the Scan offline QR Code option to set up 3rd party authenticators.

In the response received during Step 2

The policy evaluation happens in the background and the next applicable operation (either enrollment or authentication) is sent in the response.

Note that BYPASSCODE is missing in the response since the user can't enroll using a Bypass Code. The Bypass Code should be generated by the user using My Profile or by requesting that an administrator generate one for them.

item.name: Step 3: Initiate Online TOTP Enrollment Request

request.description:
This step makes the request to enroll in an online TOTP. You must include in this request the requestState that was received in the Step 2 response. 

In the Response:

The requestState in the response contains the following information:
- deviceId
- creationTime
- tenantName
- appName

Note that the value for "content" always begins with "oraclemobileauthenticator//"

To get a QR Code to scan for testing purposes:

You must copy the value of the qrCode "content" value and use an online QR Code Generator (such as: https://www.the-qrcode-generator.com) to generate a QR Code to scan using the Oracle Mobile Authenticator App to get the otpCode to use in Step 4.

Note: See Step 4a for the "Pending" response example. 

The requestState in the response contains the following information:

- requestId
- deviceId
- creationTime
- tenantName

item.name: Step 4a: Submit Factor Credentials - Pending

request.description:
This step submits the requestState that was received in the Step 3 response. Note that the Request payload doesn't contain the authFactor attribute since the requestState contains it.

If the credentials attribute is empty in the request, then the following are the optional responses from server:

-"status"="pending" (This status appears when the OMA app to server back-channel communication is not completed)

-"status"="success" (This status appears when the OMA app to server back-channel communication is completed and the optCode verification is successful).

The client keeps polling if the "otpCode" = null every 10 secs and continues to poll for two minutes. After two minutes, the server sends the failed status.

The requestState in the response contains the following information:

- requestId
- deviceId
- creationTime
- tenantName
- appName

response.name: Success Response to Step 4a: Submit Factor Credentials

item.description:
A mobile app uses either OTP or push notifications to prove that the user has possession of the mobile device. Only the mobile app that is in possession of the user's secret key can generate a valid OTP. Provisioning the secret key can be done online or offline. 
 
This enrollment scenario is using the user's credentials, the requestState, and the online MFA TOTP.

item.name: SMS Enrollment
Step 1: Authentication Request with no Tokens/Session

request.description:
This step obtains the initial requestState to then continue with the authentication flow. The appName is optional, but is used in this step for testing purposes.

The user submits their credentials in Step 2 as the first factor, which is the username/password.

The requestState in the response received contains the following information:

- creationTime
- tenantName
- appName
- ecid (to keep track of the audit trail)

For the Next Step:
- The client must pass the credentials, which are the username and password
- The client must pass the requestState that was received in the Step 1 response (this step).

This step requests to enroll in the EMAIL factor. You must include in this request the requestState that was received in the Step 2 response.

The response indicates that the client should submit the otpCode that was received in an email in the next step request.

The nextOp attribute also includes the resendCode value, which allows the user to request that the OTP be resent again in an email (see Step 3a: EMAIL enrollment Request - Resend OTP)

The nextOp attribute also includes the enrollment value, which allows the user to switch to another factor during enrollment (see the Switch to Another Factor During Enrollment folder).

item.name: Step 4: Submit Factor Credentials

request.description:
This step submits the factor credentials, which are the questionId and answers (and optionally a hint) to the security questions that the user wants to answer when prompted to authenticate. This step also includes the requestState that was received in the Step 3 response, and the Accept-Language Header.

In the response:

"nextOp": "createToken" indicates that the client can request the token in the next request.

The user can also choose to continue to enroll in other factors. Should the user continue to enroll, an extra call should be made to get the details of all factors (Get Backup Factors) that a user can enroll in.

request.description:
This step sends the username and password and the requestState that was received in the Step 1 response.

In the response received during Step 2 
"nextOp": "enrollment" indicates that the user should enroll in an MFA factor as the next step.

Note that BYPASSCODE is missing in the response since the user can't enroll using a Bypass Code. The Bypass Code should be generated by the user using My Profile or by requesting that an administrator generate one for them.

The policy evaluation happens in the background and the next applicable operation (either enrollment or authentication) is sent in the response.

Note that there is no need to include credentials in the request, since PUSH Notifications are being used.

-   creationTime
-   tenantName
-   appName
-   ecid

To get a QR Code to scan for testing purposes:

You must copy the value of the qrCode "content" value and use an online QR Code Generator (such as: https://www.the-qrcode-generator.com) to generate a QR Code to scan using the Oracle Mobile Authenticator App to get the otpCode to use in Step 4.

item.name: Step 4a: Submit Factor Credentials - Pending

request.description:
This step submits the requestState that was received in the Step 3 response. Note that the Request payload doesn't contain the authFactor attribute since the requestState contains it.

The requestState in the request contains:
- deviceId
- requestId
- authFactor

If the credentials attribute is empty in the request, then the following are the optional responses from server:

-"status"="pending" (This status appears when the OMA app to server back-channel communication is not completed)

-"status"="success" (This status appears when the OMA app to server back-channel communication is completed and the optCode verification is successful).

The client keeps polling if the "otpCode" = null every 10 secs and continues to poll for two minutes. After two minutes, the server sends the failed status.

The requestState in the response contains the following information:

-deviceId
-requestId
-authFactor
-creationTime
-tenantName
-appName

item.name: Step 3: Initiate EMAIL Enrollment Request

request.description:
This step requests to enroll in the EMAIL factor. You must include in this request the requestState that was received in the Step 2 response.

The response indicates that the client should submit the otpCode that was received in an email in the next step request.

The nextOp attribute also includes the resendCode value, which allows the user to request that the OTP be resent in an email.

The nextOp attribute also includes the enrollment value, which allows the user to switch to another factor during enrollment (see the Switch to Another Factor During Enrollment folder).

item.name: Authentication Using User Name/Password + MFA Authentication
Security Questions
Authentication With Security Questions Set as the Default Method
Step 1: Authentication Request with no Tokens/Session

request.description:
This step obtains the initial requestState to then continue with the authentication flow. The appName is optional, but is used in this step for testing purposes.

The user submits their credentials in Step 2 as the first factor, which is the username/password.

The requestState in the response received contains the following information:

- creationTime
- tenantName
- appName
- ecid (to keep track of the audit trail)

For the Next Step:
- The client must pass the credentials, which are the username and password
- The client must pass the requestState that was received in the Step 1 response (this step).

item.description:
If a user wants to use Security Questions to log in, and if Security Questions aren't the default method, the user is required to make an additional request to complete the authentication.
 
Step 3
The additional request is to obtain the backup methods available and the requestState.

In the response, locate the question to use as the security question backup method and the requestState.
 
Step 4
For security questions, use the question provided in the response from the request to obtain the backup methods, and then provide the answer and the requestState to get the access token.

item.description:
If a user wants to use EMAIL to log in, and if EMAIL is not the default method, the user is required to make two requests to complete the authentication.
 
Step 3
The first request is to obtain the backup methods available.

For email, locate the deviceId for Email provided in the response and the requestState.
 
Step 4 
The second request includes the OTP that the user receives through email. (This information can be extracted from the getBackupFactors call).

When the SDK receives a credSubmit on EMAIL, with the deviceId, it understands that it first needs to send an EMAIL with the OTP code.

item.name: Authentication With Offline TOTP & Setting Trusted Device
Step 1: Authentication Request with no Tokens/Session

request.description:
This step obtains the initial requestState to then continue with the authentication flow. The appName is optional, but is used in this step for testing purposes.

The user submits their credentials in Step 2 as the first factor, which is the username/password.

The requestState in the response received contains the following information:

- creationTime
- tenantName
- appName
- ecid (to keep track of the audit trail)

For the Next Step:
- The client must pass the credentials, which are the username and password
- The client must pass the requestState that was received in the Step 1 response (this step).

item.name: SMS
Authentication With SMS Set as the Default Method

request.description:
This step obtains the initial requestState to then continue with the authentication flow. The appName is optional, but is used in this step for testing purposes.

The user submits their credentials in Step 2 as the first factor, which is the username/password.

The requestState in the response received contains the following information:

- creationTime
- tenantName
- appName
- ecid (to keep track of the audit trail)

For the Next Step:
- The client must pass the credentials, which are the username and password
- The client must pass the requestState that was received in the Step 1 response (this step).

item.description:
If a user wants to use SMS to log in, and if SMS is not the default method, the user is required to make additional requests to complete the authentication.
 
Step 3
This request is to obtain the backup methods available and the requestState.

In the response, locate the deviceId for SMS to use and the requestState.

Step 4
This request includes deviceId and the requestState to initate SMS. When the SDK receives a credSubmit on SMS, with the deviceId, it understands that it first needs to send an SMS with the OTP code.

Step 5
This request includes the OTP that the user received on their device in response to Step 4. Since a user account can have many phone numbers enrolled, the user needs to provide the deviceId when requesting access.

item.name: PUSH Notification

Step 1: Authentication Request with no Tokens/Session

request.description:
This step obtains the initial requestState to then continue with the authentication flow. The appName is optional, but is used in this step for testing purposes.

The user submits their credentials in Step 2 as the first factor, which is the username/password.

The requestState in the response received contains the following information:

- creationTime
- tenantName
- appName
- ecid (to keep track of the audit trail)

For the Next Step:
- The client must pass the credentials, which are the username and password
- The client must pass the requestState that was received in the Step 1 response (this step).

If the factor credentials are correct, an access token and a trustToken is received in the response.

The trustToken in the response contains the following information:

-trustId
-token (UUID)
-userId
-expiryDate

Three Response examples are provided:

Pending Response
Success Response After Pending
Failed Response

item.name: Step 5: Submit Factor Credentials

request.description:
This step submits the requestState that was received in the Step 4 response. Note that the Request payload doesn't contain the authFactor attribute since the requestState contains it.

The requestState in the request contains:
- deviceId
- requestId
- authFactor

1) If the credentials attribute is empty in the request, then the following are the optional responses from server:

-"nextop"="credSubmit" (if the OMA app to server back-channel communication is not completed)

-"nextop"="createToken" (if the OMA app to server back-channel communication is completed and otpCode verification is successful).

-"nextop"="setCookie" (if OMA app to server back-channel communication is completed and otoCode verification is successful).

2) The client keeps polling every 10 secs and continues to poll for two minutes. After two minutes, the server sends the failed status.

item.description: These steps describe the authentication flow when the user wants to set a specific factor as the default factor. After the user submits their username/password, all available backup factors are requested, and then the factor to be set as the default is sent in the request with the appropriate factor credentials.
Test using the user's credentials, requestState, and Multi-Factor Authentication.

item.name: Authentication Using User Name/Password + Terms Of Use
Step 1 : Authentication Request with AppName

request.description:
The user tries to access an application that is associated with TOU. Identity Cloud Service uses this to fetch the policy that is assigned to this application. Based on the tenant settings, the server gets the Identity Provider (IDP) and authentication policy that is associated with this app and then guides the user on the next step.

For the Next Step:

- The client must pass the credentials, which are the username and password

- The client must pass the requestState that was received in the Step 1 response (this step).

response.name: Response to initial /sso/v1/sdk/authenticate?appName=appname

item.name: Step 2: Username/Password Submission (No MFA)

request.description:
In this scenario, the user is prompted to verify username-password. The following must be included in the request:

    credentials: user name and password
    requestState: received in the Step 1 response
    op: tells the server what kind of operation the client wants

The server provides the TOU statement in the locale specified in the user's profile. The server also prompts the user to provide thier "consent" credential" in the next request.

If the TOU is not present in the user's locale, then 401 response with the error message,,AUTH-3036 : Terms of Use Statement for locale fr is not added, is displayed.

response.name: TOU Statement is displayed (No MFA)
Error Example: TOU statement for locale not found
Error Example: User Name Password Authentication Failure

item.name: Step 3: TOU Consent Request Payload Example

request.description:
In this use case scenario, the user accepts or rejects their consent. If user agrees to Terms of Use (TOU), then the user is redirected to the application page.

The following must be included in the request:

- requestState: received in the Step 2 response
- op: tells the server what kind of operation the client wants, in this case "acceptTOU" with "consent": true

response.name: Error Example: AuthN Token Issue Failed (Consent = False)
Authn Token Issued (Consent = True)

item.description: In this use case scenario assumes that the administrator has enabled Terms of Use in the Identity Cloud Service admin console. When the user tries to access an application after submitting their username and password, the user is prompted to provide their Terms of Use (TOU) consent. When the user accepts the consent, then the user is re-directed to that application page.

item.name: Authentication Using User Name/Password + Enroll in Account Recovery With No MFA
Enroll With SMS + Security Questions with No MFA
Step 1: Authentication Request with AppName

request.description:
This step obtains the initial requestState to then continue with the authentication flow. The appName is optional, but is used in this step for testing purposes.

The user submits their credentials in Step 2 as the first factor, which is the username/password.

The requestState in the response received contains the following information:

- creationTime
- tenantName
- appName

For the Next Step:
- The client must pass the credentials, which are the username and password
- The client must pass the requestState that was received in the Step 1 response (this step).

response.name: Response to Step 1: Authentication Request with AppName

item.name: Step 2: Username/Password Submission (No MFA)

request.description:
The following must be included in the request:

credentials: user name and password
requestState: received in the Step 1 response
op: tells the server what kind of operation the client wants

In the response:

accRecEnrollmentRequired:true indicates Account Recovery should be prompted for.

nextAuthFactors contains the available Account Recovery Factors.

response.name: Error Example: User Name Password Authentication Failure
Response to Step 2: Username/Password Submission (No MFA)

item.name: Step 3: Initiate SMS Enrollment Request

request.description:
This step requests to enroll in the SMS factor for Account Recovery. You must include in this request the requestState that was received in the Step 2 response.

The request contains the phone number, including country code, that is to be registered for SMS.

In the response:
The nextOp value indicates that the client should submit the factor credentials (the OTP) in the next step.

response.name: Response to Step 3: Initiate SMS Enrollment Request

item.name: Step 3a: SMS Enrollment Request - Resend SMS

request.description:
This step requests to have the OTP code resent ("op":"resendCode") and contains the requestState that was received in the Step 2 response.

The requestState in the response contains the following:

- phoneNumber
- deviceId
- requestId
- tenantName
- appName
- ecid

response.name: Response to Step 3a: SMS Enrollment Request - Resend SMS

item.name: Step 4: Submit Factor Credentials for SMS Enrollment

request.description:
This step submits the factor credentials and the requestState that was received in the Step 3 response.

The otpCode is the code received via SMS when enrollment was initiated.

"authFactor": "SMS" is removed from request payload as this is present in requestState, along with deviceId and requestId.

In the response:

"nextOp": "createToken" indicates that the client can request the token in the next request.

The user can also choose to continue to enroll in other factors. Should the user continue to enroll, an extra call should be made to get the details of all factors (Get Backup Factors) that a user can enroll in.

response.name: Response to Step 4: Submit Factor Credentials for SMS Enrollment

item.name: Step 5: Request to View Other Factors for Enrollment

request.description:
This step requests to view what other factors can be enrolled in. You must include in this request the requestState that was received in the previous response.

The values for the "nextAuthFactors" attribute in the response are the factors that the user can enroll in next.

The nextOp attribute includes the "enrollment" value, which also allows the user to switch to another factor during enrollment (see the Switch to Another Factor During Enrollment folder).

response.name: Response to Step 5: Request to View Other Factors for Enrollment

item.name: Step 6: Initiate Security Questions Enrollment Request

request.description:
This step requests to enroll in the Security Questions factor. You must include in this request the requestState that was received in the Step 5 response.

In the response:
 
The response includes all of the available questions that a user can answer. The "numQuestionsToSetup" value defines how many questions that the user must answer in the next step request.

The requestState in the response contains the following information:

- creationTime
- tenantName
- appName
- ecid

response.name: Response to Step 6: Initiate Security Questions Enrollment Request

item.name: Step 7: Submit Factor Credentials for Security Questions Enrollment

request.description:
This step submits the factor credentials, which are the questionId and answers (and optionally a hint) to the security questions that the user wants to answer when prompted to authenticate. This step also includes the requestState that was received in the Step 6 response, and the Accept-Language Header.

In the response:

"nextOp": "createToken" indicates that the client can request the token in the next request.

The user can also choose to continue to enroll in other factors. Should the user continue to enroll, an extra call should be made to get the details of all factors (Get Backup Factors) that a user can enroll in.

response.name: Response to Step 7: Submit Factor Credentials for Security Questions Enrollment

item.name: Step 8: Create Token After Enrollment is Complete

request.description:
This step replicates the "Done" functionality where the client says "I am done with all authnFactors and need a session created".

The server validates that no other factor evaluation (depending on what is defined for the policy) is needed and responds with the token or denies access.

response.name: Response to Step 8: Create Token After Enrollment is Complete

item.description: Test authentication, enroll in SMS and Security Questions for account recovery, using the user's credentials and the requestState.
Test authentication and account recovery enrollment using the user's credentials and the requestState.

item.name: Step 6: Set SMS as Overlap for MFA

request.description: In this step SMS is enrolled for MFA. The accountRecoveryFactor is set to true since we are using the already enrolled Account Recovery factor for MFA.

response.name: Response to Step 6: Set SMS as Overlap for MFA

item.name: Step 7: Request to View Other Factors for Enrollment

request.description:
This step requests to view what other factors can be enrolled in for MFA . You must include in this request the requestState that was received in the previous response.

The values for the "nextAuthFactors" attribute in the response are the factors that the user can enroll in next.

The nextOp attribute includes the "enrollment" value, which also allows the user to switch to another factor during enrollment (see the Switch to Another Factor During Enrollment folder).

response.name: Response to Step 7: Request to View Other Factors for Enrollment

item.name: Step 8: Initiate Online TOTP Enrollment Request

request.description:
This step makes the request to enroll in an online TOTP for MFA. You must include in this request the requestState that was received in the Step 7 response. 

In the Response:

The requestState in the response contains the following information:
- deviceId
- creationTime
- tenantName
- appName

Note that the value for "content" always begins with "oraclemobileauthenticator//"

To get a QR Code to scan for testing purposes:

You must copy the value of the qrCode "content" value and use an online QR Code Generator (such as: https://www.the-qrcode-generator.com) to generate a QR Code to scan using the Oracle Mobile Authenticator App to get the otpCode to use in Step 9.

response.name: Response to Step 8: Initiate Online TOTP Enrollment Request

item.name: Step 9: Submit Factor Credentials

request.description:
This step submits the requestState that was received in the Step 8 response. Note that the Request payload doesn't contain the authFactor attribute since the requestState contains it.

Note: See Step 9a for the "Pending" response example. 

The requestState in the response contains the following information:

- requestId
- deviceId
- creationTime
- tenantName
- appName

response.name: Response to Step 9: Submit Factor Credentials

item.name: Step 9a: Submit Factor Credentials - Pending

request.description:
This step submits the requestState that was received in the Step 8 response. Note that the Request payload doesn't contain the authFactor attribute since the requestState contains it.

If the credentials attribute is empty in the request, then the following are the optional responses from server:

-"status"="pending" (This status appears when the OMA app to server back-channel communication is not completed)

-"status"="success" (This status appears when the OMA app to server back-channel communication is completed and the optCode verification is successful).

The client keeps polling if the "otpCode" = null every 10 secs and continues to poll for two minutes. After two minutes, the server sends the failed status.

The requestState in the response contains the following information:

- requestId
- deviceId
- creationTime
- tenantName
- appName

response.name: Success Response to Step 9a: Submit Factor Credentials

header.name: Content-length
header.description: The length of the response body in octets (8-bit bytes)

response.name: Pending Response to Step 9a: Submit Factor Credentials for Online TOTP Enrollment

item.name: Step 10: Create Token After Enrollment is Complete

request.description:
This step replicates the "Done" functionality where the client says "I am done with all authnFactors and need a session created".

The server validates that no other factor evaluation (depending on what is defined for the policy) is needed and responds with the token or denies access.

response.name: Response to Step 10: Create Token After Enrollment is Complete

item.description: Test authentication, SMS enrollment for account recovery, and SMS and Online One-Time Passcode (TOTP) for  Multi-Factor Authentication enrollment using the user's credentials and the requestState.
Test authentication, account recovery and Multi-Factor Authentication enrollment using the user's credentials and the requestState.
